div1.head: Recollections of the Yellow Fever Commission, by Jefferson Randolph Kean, May 11, 1946

list.head: Memo of Answers-
list.item:
1. I knew from Major Reed that he was in contact with
Dr. L. O. Howard of the Dept. of Agriculture before he came
to Cuba- I had learned from him when he visited me
at Key West I think in 1896 of Howard's use of kerosene
to combat the breeding of mosquitos and had recom-
mended it to the municipal authorities to control the
mosquito pest in the numerous shallow ponds,
on the upper end of the island near the U. S. Mil.-
Reservation, where it could easily have been applied, but
they were accustomed to mosquitos and took no action-
Whether Lazear knew Dr. Howard I doubt- He had studied
(no)
mosquitos and malaria in Italy- My impression is that
(c
Dr. Welsh of Johns Hopkins knew of his work and
mentioned his name to Dr. Reed as a mosquito expert-
Dr. Reed was my only source of knowledge as to his
study of mosquitos with Howard- I dont know
about Carroll, who I think was not interested in
mosquitos-
2. I do not know

3- My notebook (REF) says p. 38 that Reed came to Havana
to inspect Electrozone plant March 10, 1900
He came again to investigate typhoid outbreak in Puerto Principe
in May 1900 & lunched with me May 4, 1900-
(Meree to tell Dr. Hench story of Electrozone-)

4 I do not know who initiated the formation of the Y. F. Board
I have always believed that Gen- Sternberg initiated it

5 I think that Trubys idea was correct about Welch recommending
Lazear to Reed but have no definite authority for it-

Ac
K
Page 2- J. R. K. to P. S. Hench-
6- I do not know-

7. I do not know except that the N. Y. line to Havana had
put on much larger and steadyer boats

8. I think that most of Reeds trip were by merchant
lines - would it be worth the trouble to try to get the
transports passenger lists? I doubt it. I will put
down the dates I know-
Reed came to Cuba about May 3 1900 typhoid in Puerto Principe
" " " " March 10 to look in Electrozone plant
" " " " June 25 with Carroll for Y. F. Con
" left Cuba for U. S. Aug. 2 1900
" returned to Cuba Oct. 4, 1900 on transport “Crook”
" left " for U. S. Feb. 1901 Oct. 14, 1900
Returned to Cuba early in Nov (Truby) 1900 - see above
9- Where is the photograph of Reed.

10- See page 76 Truby's book about Reed's return to study
yellow fever- I do not remember when I had the
first news of the appointment of the Reed Board
Truby says with reference to the selection of the Reed Board
p. 181. "About the middle of May 1900 Sternberg and Reed
had a conference and at that time they planned the
Campaign and selected the members of the Board

11- Camp Columbia was under quarantine and military authories
wouldmight not permit infected mosquitos to be brought in to the
laboratory if they knew about it-

12. Reeds authority from the S. Y. would not prevent the local control
of the Camp C. O. from stopping the work of the Board on the reservation
unless the Board were backed by higher line authority-
13. No not in 1900-
14 Second floor front room at right center-
Palace

15 It was the Immigrant Detention Camp under the
authority of Menocal- It needs a map to locate it.

16- The Spaniards were engaged by Reed thru an interpreter
I do not know details-
17 I dont know
18- I do not know
19- I do not know
20- My memory is hazy as to details

21 My acquaintance with Lazear was rather casual until
we went together to inspect y. f. suspects in Marianao
where he examined with interest the mosquitos in the
buildings no. 20 Gen Lee St. where Sergt King Sherwood
lived- Also a packer named King
23- I do not think so. They were very simple structures

22. There was no official connection until Gen Wood
placed the money for Camp Lazear & the Commission
to Kean's account for disbursement-
24 It was quite enthusiastic

25 It was not regarded as unusual as it was well
known that he had yellow fever. Kean sailed Monday
Wed 19th Sept on Sedgwick for Crenpingos with Col Howard
returned to Havana Sept 24 Monday when we heard of Cartwright
death- Dr. Lazear was very ill and died on 25th-
On Oct 3 Kean went to Matanja with Col Havard and saw
Reed returning from Wash on the Transport Crook & told
him of Lazears death-

Ac
K

26 I think so- In history we must not
conceal people's mistakes in writing history

27 Look up the med circulars of instructions formal
from Ch Surg Office- They required a record
of temperature pulse and urine to be kept in each
case of fever. Special attention to certain diagnostic
features which would put the doctor on guard
us a slow pulse with fever and early appearance
of albumen in the urine- These instructions were formal
and compliance was expected in all wards cases-
28- My recollection is in accord with Gen Trubys

29 Kean is probably responsible for failure to do something
special for Moran- It seemed natural to reward
with a promotion the first member of the H. C.
who had a case of experimental y. f. but not every
other man- The gold watch was bought from the money
which Kissinger declined (but he was willing to take
the watch and the balance of the money) I would have
been glad to buy a watch for Moran on the same
times but he diclined any reward- I never
knew that his feelings were hurt until Col. Hench
told me of it. The ceremony must have occurred betw Jan 9 & Jan 29
Col. Havard Chief Surgeon left Cuba Nov. 19th-1900
articles in Discussion Diary V p 13- Kissing was bitten
Nov 22. So could notmay have been Havard who was the
Chief Surgeon He returned Jan 8th and may have given it between cor
Med 30th-Jan
10-20th
I wrote Dec. 19 to Surg. Gen. recommending Carroll as Major Surg. Vols
Col Havard I left Havana Wed Jan 30 for Wash. Returned Feb. 20 1901,

Questionnaire-

Q 31- Any one's guess is as good as anothers
mine is it was pasted over to hide it in case search was
made for it-
Q. 32 Incidents about Dr Finlay- Gorgas's story-
Q 33 About what?

Q 34- Reed was greatly disgusted that Carroll should go into
infected localities- Havana (Agramontes autopsy room)
after being bitten by infected mosquitos in this way viciating
the experiment- I do not know if he reproached Carroll
the damage was done-
35- I do not know, I was never there

36. The death of Miss Maas occurred June 23, the first experimental
death was June 15 1900 Carroll was in Cuba and duced
with me on June 16th He was conducting blood infection tests
under Reed's orders- I never heard Reed mention those
Cases of Guiteras and Gorgas-

37. I dont know, in the S. G. O. perhaps but it will not have any informa-
tion that we do not know- I probably made it-
38 I dont know
39 Very interesting and doubtless true
40 What about the lost Finlay book?
41- I fear that it true
42 would like to see it

43. Yes it seems so- I do not remember how it was done - probably
by a special act- I was probably in Cuba then
44 Reed's letter of July 1900

45- It was an Artillery Captain from Sta. Clara Battery
He made no official complaint I think-
46- No one-

47- Reed told me of the talk with XY and in much the same
words as it is told by Truby in his book p. 122
“I think I would like that coin but I have not been off the
post-”

48- It has always puzzled me that he should have apparently
accepted it-

50- There was an exchange of letters when Reed work to Gorgas
congratulating him on his conversion -
(mem to March for date)

51. Will try to locate that date too I got it from Gorgas
There may have been some correspondence between
the Health Dept of Cuba and the U S Pub Health
about it- I do not know.
52 Policy-

53 It was different in different individuals but no panic
Wives and children of American usually went to U S
The soldiers were in quarantine and did not seem
to worry

56 ? Explain- I was study up various points with reference
to my examination This was one on which I had
no data
